review: The Chromecast does everything it says it will. You can cast the free Hulu with it, whereas with the Roku you can't. (Unless someone has discovered something I haven't.) Basically any video you can pull up on your web browser, you can cast to your TV. You can also stream videos and movies from your computer. With all that said, I do actually prefer the Roku. The Roku is easier for me to operate and work with, not that the Chromecast is that difficult. The Roku may be a tad more limited in what you can watch from the Internet, but the majority of what you will find with Chromecast can be found on at least one of the Roku channels. For the price, about half what a month's cable costs, you could buy both and not loose any sleep. You probably don't really need both though. Being an old movie and television nut, I can find plenty of movies and old television series on YouTube. YouTube is about all I use my Chromecast or Roku for, so I actually would be happy with either one.
author: T. Barnard "magnum7"

review: I've worked closely with this product for a long time and I can assure you that it is the best wireless option to view your videos. We have two, one for the living room and one for the bedroom and they work great. No need to unplug and move the PS3 around.Tip: if your Google Play Video isn't playing correctly try YouTube. You will find an option that says purchases under the left-hand menu. YouTube is owned by Google and it 99% of the time will work just fine. Google is just a little new to the video player game and it's still working out the kinks.
